articles.headline: Egg Donors Challenge Pay Rates, Saying They Shortchange Women
articles.snippet: A federal class-action suit questions compensation guidelines in a largely unregulated industry and seeks to increase donors’ negotiating power.
articles.abstract: A federal class-action suit questions compensation guidelines in a largely unregulated industry and seeks to increase donors’ negotiating power.
articles.lead_paragraph: On their websites, next to glossy pictures of babies, some fertility clinics and egg-donor agencies refer to eggs as a “priceless gift” from caring young women who want to help people with fertility problems. There is a price tag for eggs, though, and it is now the subject of a legal battle.

articles.headline: Afghan Plan to Expand Militia Raises Abuse Concerns
articles.snippet: Facing an aggressive offensive from the Taliban, the government wants to expand the Afghan Local Police, despite their troubled history.
articles.abstract: Facing an aggressive offensive from the Taliban, the government wants to expand the Afghan Local Police, despite their troubled history.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — With the Afghan security forces gravely challenged by Taliban offensives, the government is moving to rapidly expand the troubled Afghan Local Police program by thousands of members, Afghan and Western officials say.

articles.headline: Retirees’ Futures Hinge on Candidates’ Plans for Social Security
articles.snippet: Democrats are calling for higher-income workers to pay more in payroll taxes, while Republicans’ proposals focus on cutting benefits.
articles.abstract: Democrats are calling for higher-income workers to pay more in payroll taxes, while Republicans’ proposals focus on cutting benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 81, Sara Moore still occasionally drives five blocks to the grocery store in her 1993 Buick, which her son had painted pink for breast cancer awareness. She is a survivor.

articles.headline: Identity Chaos, Courtesy of Your Federal Government
articles.snippet: It took the combined efforts of the Treasury Department and the Education Department to bring a psychologist named Victoria Schindler to the brink.
articles.abstract: It took the combined efforts of the Treasury Department and the Education Department to bring a psychologist named Victoria Schindler to the brink.
articles.lead_paragraph: The year 2015 may set a new standard for shoulder-shrugging after identity thefts and data breaches that ought to provoke outrage.

articles.headline: Coal Baron’s Trial May Hinge on His Secretly Recorded Conversations
articles.snippet: Prosecutors have played 19 snippets from the audio files of Donald L. Blankenship, who is charged with felonies related to a blast that killed 29 miners in West Virginia.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors have played 19 snippets from the audio files of Donald L. Blankenship, who is charged with felonies related to a blast that killed 29 miners in West Virginia.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Back when he was one of the most powerful and feared men in West Virginia, before a coal mine explosion killed 29 of his employees and exposed his company’s shoddy safety record, Donald L. Blankenship was seen as an arrogant, micromanaging bully. Even his lawyer says he was “rude and insulting.”

articles.headline: Theranos, a Blood Test Start-Up, Faces F.D.A. Scrutiny
articles.snippet: In response to questions raised by the Food and Drug Administration, the medical testing start-up has temporarily stopped its signature practice of collecting tiny blood samples from finger pricks.
articles.abstract: In response to questions raised by the Food and Drug Administration, the medical testing start-up has temporarily stopped its signature practice of collecting tiny blood samples from finger pricks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Theranos, a closely watched start-up that vowed to revolutionize medical testing, said on Friday that because of questions raised by the Food and Drug Administration, it had temporarily halted its trademark practice of collecting tiny blood samples from finger pricks.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Bets on Future With Spending Spree to Build Campaign Infrastructure
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton, using lessons learned from the 2008 campaign, has built a cash-hungry campaign to build an unparalleled infrastructure that could morph into a general election machine.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton, using lessons learned from the 2008 campaign, has built a cash-hungry campaign to build an unparalleled infrastructure that could morph into a general election machine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has spent more than twice as much as any other presidential candidate on campaign staff, more than three times as much on office space and millions of dollars more on advertising, according to reports filed this week with the Federal Election Commission.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Maggie Haberman and Sarah Cohen

articles.headline: Indian Writers Return Awards to Protest Government Silence on Violence
articles.snippet: The revolt now confronts Prime Minister Narendra Modi with a critical test of his vaunted ability to shape the public narrative of his administration.
articles.abstract: The revolt now confronts Prime Minister Narendra Modi with a critical test of his vaunted ability to shape the public narrative of his administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The novelist Nayantara Sahgal said she was returning India’s highest literary honor to express sympathy for “all dissenters who now live in fear and uncertainty.” G. S. Bhullar, a short-story author, said he was giving back the same award to protest the “violent retrogressive forces dictating terms in the field of literature and culture.” Mandakranta Sen, a Bengali poet, said she was sending her award back to protest “attacks on rationalists.”
articles.byline: By David Barstow and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: A Small Indiana Town Scarred by a Trusted Doctor
articles.snippet: Nearly 300 patients have filed lawsuits against a local cardiologist and his two partners, claiming that they performed needless operations.
articles.abstract: Nearly 300 patients have filed lawsuits against a local cardiologist and his two partners, claiming that they performed needless operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNSTER, Ind. — On a spring evening last year, Debra Davidson flipped on the television to watch the local news. When an item came on about her longtime physician, she perked up and leaned forward. Then she screamed. Her husband rushed into the living room to see if everything was O.K.

articles.headline: Challenging Private Equity Fees Tucked in Footnotes
articles.snippet: California’s treasurer wants the $3.9 trillion industry to be clearer about what it charges investors, and some expect other states to follow.
articles.abstract: California’s treasurer wants the $3.9 trillion industry to be clearer about what it charges investors, and some expect other states to follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much do private equity investors pay to the firms overseeing their portfolios?

articles.headline: Firefighters’ Union Owes Clout to Its Free-Spending Chief
articles.snippet: Harold Schaitberger, head of the International Association of Fire Fighters, makes no apologies for the lavish spending he believes is necessary to wield power.
articles.abstract: Harold Schaitberger, head of the International Association of Fire Fighters, makes no apologies for the lavish spending he believes is necessary to wield power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The International Association of Fire Fighters is a small union of just under 300,000 members with political influence far beyond its size. The obvious reason for this is the respect many Americans have for firefighters, who consistently rank as some of the country’s most admired professionals. The less obvious reason is Harold A. Schaitberger, a tall, barrel-chested man with meaty hands and rheumy eyes, who has served as the union’s general president for over 15 years.

articles.headline: East Jerusalem, Bubbling Over With Despair
articles.snippet: East Jerusalem, long the emotional heart of Palestinian life, is now the fiery soul of its discontent: Its residents feel neglected by the Israeli government and the Palestinian Authority.
articles.abstract: East Jerusalem, long the emotional heart of Palestinian life, is now the fiery soul of its discontent: Its residents feel neglected by the Israeli government and the Palestinian Authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — East Jerusalem, long the emotional heart of Palestinian life, is now the fiery soul of its discontent.

articles.headline: A Veterans of Foreign Wars Post in Denver Trades Beer for a Sun Salute
articles.snippet: By abandoning the traditional model of a dim, members-only tavern in favor of a bright gallery space with yoga, the V.F.W.’s oldest post has been transformed.
articles.abstract: By abandoning the traditional model of a dim, members-only tavern in favor of a bright gallery space with yoga, the V.F.W.’s oldest post has been transformed.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — At a meeting in the country’s oldest Veterans of Foreign Wars post, a Marine began by asking members to close their eyes and inhale.

articles.headline: Few in Venezuela Want Bolívars, but No One Can Spare a Dime
articles.snippet: The country’s currency has crashed along with its economy, despite an unchanging official exchange rate, transforming economic absurdities into daily hardships.
articles.abstract: The country’s currency has crashed along with its economy, despite an unchanging official exchange rate, transforming economic absurdities into daily hardships.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Pity the bolívar, Venezuela’s currency, named after its independence hero, Simón Bolívar. Even some thieves do not want it anymore.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Patricia Torres

articles.headline: Open Doors and Lingering Pain at Charleston Church Where 9 Were Killed
articles.snippet: As Emanuel A.M.E. Church copes with the killing of nine members in June, it is seeing more white visitors, while its interim pastor faces questions.
articles.abstract: As Emanuel A.M.E. Church copes with the killing of nine members in June, it is seeing more white visitors, while its interim pastor faces questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The Rev. Dr. Norvel Goff Sr. was standing on a Wednesday evening in the room where the massacre occurred at Emanuel A.M.E. Church, readying himself to lead Bible study.

articles.headline: Rwanda Aid Shows Reach and Limits of Clinton Foundation
articles.snippet: In addition to doing good deeds, the foundation enhances the Clinton brand, never more so than while Hillary Rodham Clinton is running for president.
articles.abstract: In addition to doing good deeds, the foundation enhances the Clinton brand, never more so than while Hillary Rodham Clinton is running for president.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — In a resurgent Rwanda, only 21 years past the genocide, the government of President Paul Kagame has deputized a high-profile partner for an array of endeavors across this striving, haunted land: in a banana grove in Kayonza, where subsistence farmers are learning to double their yields; in a teaching hospital in Kigali, where American and Rwandan faculty are training a generation of specialists and nurses; in a sprawling plant in Mukarange, where soybeans are being processed into the country’s first domestic cooking oil.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Essential Part of the Volkswagen Diesel Repair Is the Owner
articles.snippet: For the most part, owners are not required to have repairs made to Volkswagen cars whose emissions systems were modified to cheat federal tests.
articles.abstract: For the most part, owners are not required to have repairs made to Volkswagen cars whose emissions systems were modified to cheat federal tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as Volkswagen embarks on the task of fixing the emissions systems it disabled on almost 500,000 of its diesel vehicles in the United States, the automaker faces another hurdle: persuading owners to make the repair at all.

articles.headline: Publishers Straddle the Apple-Google, App-Web Divide
articles.snippet: As Apple focuses on apps and Google pushes the mobile web, businesses must grapple with a fragmenting online world.
articles.abstract: As Apple focuses on apps and Google pushes the mobile web, businesses must grapple with a fragmenting online world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple wants mobile devices to be filled with apps. Google supports a world where people browse the web for most things. Now websites are increasingly caught in the middle of those competing visions.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: Netflix Faces Challengers in Its Push to Expand Globally
articles.snippet: International competitors are offering similar fare, and even some of Netflix’s programming, making it harder for the video-streaming service to gain traction.
articles.abstract: International competitors are offering similar fare, and even some of Netflix’s programming, making it harder for the video-streaming service to gain traction.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, Miguel Díez Ferreira would seem to make an ideal customer for Netflix.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and Elian Peltier

articles.headline: Air Force One, a Cherished Perk Awaiting an Upgrade
articles.snippet: President Obama plans to bequeath his successor — or perhaps his successor’s successor — a new-and-improved Air Force One for the smartphone age.
articles.abstract: President Obama plans to bequeath his successor — or perhaps his successor’s successor — a new-and-improved Air Force One for the smartphone age.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has already made clear what he will miss the most when he leaves office in 15 months. “People sometimes ask me what the biggest perk of being president is,” he told visitors at the White House last week. “No. 1 is the plane.”

articles.headline: Walmart Chief Defends Investments in Labor, Stores and the Web
articles.snippet: The retail giant forecast lackluster sales growth for this year and a steep profit dip for next, in part because costs are climbing sharply as sales are flat.
articles.abstract: The retail giant forecast lackluster sales growth for this year and a steep profit dip for next, in part because costs are climbing sharply as sales are flat.
articles.lead_paragraph: He is the consummate Walmart company man.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Winter Poses New Danger for Migrants
articles.snippet: Cold weather and closing borders are complicating the arduous path from Syria and other war-torn nations into the heart of Western Europe.
articles.abstract: Cold weather and closing borders are complicating the arduous path from Syria and other war-torn nations into the heart of Western Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: OPATOVAC, Croatia — The migrants coming into Europe through the Western Balkans in recent months have been resourceful and adaptable enough to slip around unfriendly police officers, raging rivers, hostile borders and razor-wire fences. But there is one thing they cannot evade, and that is the looming winter.

articles.headline: Justin Trudeau and Liberal Party Prevail With Stunning Rout in Canada
articles.snippet: Mr. Trudeau unseated the Conservative prime minister, Stephen Harper, in a sweeping victory for the Liberal Party on Monday.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trudeau unseated the Conservative prime minister, Stephen Harper, in a sweeping victory for the Liberal Party on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The nine-year reign of Prime Minister Stephen Harper and his Conservative Party came to a sudden and stunning end on Monday night at the hands of Justin Trudeau, the young leader of the Liberal Party.

articles.headline: Republican Freedom Caucus’s Revolt in House Is Stoked Back Home
articles.snippet: Members have challenged their party’s leaders with a fury that is embraced by their constituents, interviews in five districts show.
articles.abstract: Members have challenged their party’s leaders with a fury that is embraced by their constituents, interviews in five districts show.
articles.lead_paragraph: When 87 Republican freshmen arrived in the House of Representatives in 2011 after an election swayed by the Tea Party movement swept Republicans back into the majority, the question was simple: Would they change Washington, or would Washington change them?

articles.headline: Shares of Weight Watchers Jump as Oprah Winfrey Takes a Stake
articles.snippet: Ms. Winfrey will buy newly issued shares, worth about 10 percent of the company, and take a seat on the board.
articles.abstract: Ms. Winfrey will buy newly issued shares, worth about 10 percent of the company, and take a seat on the board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Her show might be gone but the “Oprah Effect” clearly endures.
